page.title: 09Weaving in Shutford
page.content: Shutford's weaving industry was established in 1747 by Robert Lees of Banbury. The business was aquired by the Wrench family in 1815. In 1851 William Wrench employed 23 men. Power looms were introduced in 1885. A fire in Shutford in 1913 destroyed most of the machinery. The business was sold by Mr H E Wrench in 1948 to Messrs J H Walker of Dewsbury in Yorkshire and owrk at the Shutford factory came to an end. The velvet fabric produced was known as Shutford Plush. It was supplied from Shutford to most of the Royal Courts of Europe including that of Edward VII. The plush was exported to Japan, Persia and South America.
